title: Schoolchildren sing to cheer up people locked inside Parliament during terror attack

organizations.name: st john & st francis church school

text:
Ambulances wait as members of the emergency services work on Westminster Bridge (Picture: AFP/Getty Images) Schoolchildren sang to cheer up hundreds of people locked inside Parliament during the terror attack.
Police had locked down parts of Westminster after a man armed with a knife had gone on a rampage.
London terror attacker was 'Asian man in his 40s' in car registered to affluent area At least four people died as a result, including the alleged perpetrator who was shot dead by armed officers.
A police officer was also killed.
The children, who were said to be aged between ten and 12, were in the grand Central Lobby when they started singing and clapping.
MORE: How the London terror attack unfolded: Timeline of the terror attack 
What happened outside Parliament? A policeman has died after being stabbed and his apparent attacker was shot by officers in a major security incident at the Houses of Parliament.
Around three shots rang out outside the Palace of Westminster after a man ran through the gates into the front yard of the parliamentary compound apparently waving a knife.
Two people were seen being treated on the ground in New Palace Yard amid shouts and screams.
An air ambulance landed in Parliament Square and a regular ambulance came in through the front gates as medics rushed to help the injured people.
Armed police cleared the area around the incident and Parliament Square was closed to traffic.
Scotland Yard said the attack in Westminster was being treated ‘as a terrorist incident until we know otherwise’.
Up to one dozen people were also injured after a car mowed down people on Westminster Bridge.
In total, four people have died and a number of others have been hurt – including some with ‘catastrophic’ injuries – a junior doctor at St Thomas’ Hospital has said. 
‘They had a little sing song with clapping rhythm,’ Rebecca Ingle, 25, told the Mirror .
‘Eventually they sat on the floor and I didn’t hear much more of their songs, I was the other side of the room so couldn’t see.’
They were from St John & St Francis Church School in Bridgwater, Somerset, and the school’s official Twitter account later wrote: ‘We’re all sat in the centre of the #housesofparliament. We are safe, happy and lightening the mood with a sing song.’
